examples.sentence: Japanese: Each character = one consistent sound, always
Listen to pronunciation in learning tools
Use our Hiragana Practice with audio
Learn Hiragana - Audio for each character

sections.heading: Why Japanese Pronunciation is Easy
sections.content:
Unlike English with its irregular spelling and pronunciation, Japanese is phonetic - it's spelled exactly as it's pronounced. If you can read hiragana or katakana, you can pronounce the word.

Compare to English:

"through" "though" "cough" "rough" - same spelling pattern, different sounds Japanese: Each character = one consistent sound, always

sections.heading: The Five Vowels
sections.content: Japanese has only 5 vowel sounds (English has ~15). Master these and you're halfway there.

children.heading: あ (a) - "ah"
children.content:
Like "father" or "ah" at the doctor

あさ (asa) - morning たべる (taberu) - to eat

children.heading: い (i) - "ee"
children.content:
Like "see" or "bee" (short and crisp)

いえ (ie) - house きれい (kirei) - beautiful

children.heading: う (u) - "oo"
children.content:
Like "boot" but with less lip rounding . Keep lips relaxed.

うみ (umi) - ocean くる (kuru) - to come

Common mistake: English speakers round lips too much. Keep them neutral.

children.heading: え (e) - "eh"
children.content:
Like "bed" or "get"

えき (eki) - station てがみ (tegami) - letter

children.heading: お (o) - "oh"
children.content:
Like "boat" but shorter and crisper

おかね (okane) - money そら (sora) - sky

children.heading: 1. Each Sound is Equal Length
children.content:
Every syllable gets equal time - no stress accents like English.

English: "JA-pa-nese" (stress on first syllable) Japanese: "ni-ho-n-go" (equal stress on all)

children.heading: 2. Double Vowels = Held Sound
children.content:
When you see two vowels together, hold the sound longer:

おかあさん (okaasan) - mother Hold the "a" sound: o-ka-a-sa-n せんせい (sensei) - teacher Hold the "e" sound: se-n-se-i そう (sou) - so/that way Hold the "o" sound: so-o

In romaji: ā, ē, ī, ō, ū or double letters (aa, ee, ii, oo, uu)

children.heading: 3. Small っ (tsu) = Brief Pause
children.content:
The small っ (sokuon) creates a brief stop before the next consonant:

がっこう (gakkou) - school Pronounce: gak-kou (pause before k) きって (kitte) - stamp Pronounce: kit-te (pause before t) さっき (sakki) - just now Pronounce: sak-ki (pause before k)

Think of it as doubling the consonant.

children.heading: 4. ん (n) is Nasal
children.content:
The ん (n) changes slightly based on what follows:

さんぽ (sanpo) - walk → sounds like "sampo" てんぷら (tenpura) - tempura → sounds like "tempura" せんせい (sensei) - teacher → regular "n"

Don't worry too much - natives understand any variation.

sections.heading: Consonant Sounds
sections.content: Most consonants are similar to English, with a few key differences:

children.heading: R (ら行)
children.content:
Not like English R or L - it's a quick tap, like the "tt" in "butter" or Spanish "r":

ら (ra) - tap tongue on roof of mouth once りんご (ringo) - apple わたし (watashi) - I/me

children.heading: F (ふ)
children.content:
The Japanese "fu" is softer - blow air through slightly parted lips:

ふじさん (fujisan) - Mt. Fuji Not "foo" but gentler, almost "hu"

children.heading: TSU (つ)
children.content:
One syllable, not "tee-soo":

つくる (tsukuru) - to make Say "ts" like in "cats" + "u"

children.heading: H (は行)
children.content:
Keep it light, don't make it harsh:

はな (hana) - flower/nose ひと (hito) - person

children.heading: Ya, Yu, Yo (Small や、ゆ、よ)
children.content:
When combined with other consonants, they create one syllable:

きゃ (kya) - one syllable, not "ki-ya" きゅう (kyuu) - one syllable "kyuu" きょう (kyou) - today, one syllable "kyoh" Examples: りょうり (ryouri) - cooking [ryo-u-ri, 3 syllables] ぎゅうにゅう (gyuunyuu) - milk [gyu-u-nyu-u, 4 syllables]

children.heading: G vs NG Sound
children.content:
が at the start of a word is hard "g" (like "go") が in the middle often becomes nasalized "ng":

がっこう (gakkou) - school [hard g] えいが (eiga) - movie [nasalized, almost "ei-nga"]

Both pronunciations are acceptable.

sections.heading: Pitch Accent (Not Stress)
sections.content:
Japanese doesn't have stress accents like English. Instead, it uses pitch - some syllables are higher or lower in tone.

English: "REcord" (noun) vs "reCORD" (verb) - stress changes Japanese: Pitch rises or falls, volume stays same

children.heading: Common Patterns
children.content:
Pattern 1: Low-High

はし (hashi) - chopsticks Low → High はし (hashi) - bridge High → Low

The pitch pattern can change meaning! Context usually makes it clear.

Don't worry too much: Even with wrong pitch, natives understand from context. Focus on clear vowel/consonant pronunciation first.

children.heading: Mistake 1: Adding Vowels to Consonants
children.content:
Wrong: "de-su-ka" → "des-ka" Don't add extra vowels between consonants.

です (desu) → often sounds like "dess" in natural speech ます (masu) → often sounds like "mass"

children.heading: Mistake 2: English R/L
children.content: Wrong: Using English "r" or "l" for Japanese ら Right: Quick tap, tongue touches roof of mouth briefly

children.heading: Mistake 3: Stressing Syllables
children.content: Wrong: "a-RI-ga-TO-u" (stress pattern) Right: "a-ri-ga-to-u" (all equal)

children.heading: Mistake 4: Long vs Short Vowels
children.content:
These are different words:

おばさん (obasan) - aunt おばあさん (obaasan) - grandmother/old woman そ (so) - that そう (sou) - yes/that's right

Hold long vowels the full length.

children.heading: Easy Words
children.content: すし (sushi) - sushi さくら (sakura) - cherry blossom かわいい (kawaii) - cute ありがとう (arigatou) - thank you

children.heading: Medium Words
children.content: たべます (tabemasu) - to eat がくせい (gakusei) - student にほんご (nihongo) - Japanese language

children.heading: Challenging Words
children.content: りょこう (ryokou) - travel ちゅうごく (chuugoku) - China きょうしつ (kyoushitsu) - classroom

sections.heading: Devoiced Vowels
sections.content:
In fast speech, i and u between voiceless consonants often become whispered or silent:

です (desu) → sounds like "dess" します (shimasu) → sounds like "sh'mass" すき (suki) → sounds like "ski"

This happens naturally - don't force it initially.

children.heading: Statements
children.content:
End with falling pitch:

これはペンです。(kore wa pen desu) "This is a pen." ↓

children.heading: Questions
children.content:
Can rise slightly at the end, but less than English:

これはペンですか？(kore wa pen desu ka?) "Is this a pen?" ↑ (slight rise)

The か (ka) particle already marks it as a question.

sections.heading: Katakana Foreign Words
sections.content:
Foreign loanwords in katakana often sound different from original pronunciation:

コーヒー (ko-hi-) - coffee Not "coffee" but "koh-hee" アメリカ (amerika) - America Clear "a-me-ri-ka" インターネット (inta-netto) - internet "in-tah-net-to"

Follow Japanese pronunciation rules, not English.

children.heading: 1. Listen Actively
children.content: Watch Japanese content with subtitles Listen to pronunciation in learning tools Use our Hiragana Practice with audio

children.heading: 2. Shadow Speaking
children.content: Listen to a native speaker Immediately repeat what they said Match rhythm and pitch

children.heading: 3. Record Yourself
children.content: Record reading hiragana/katakana Compare to native pronunciation Notice differences

children.heading: 4. Learn Hiragana/Katakana Sounds
children.content: Our Hiragana Table has audio Our Katakana Table has audio Practice regularly

children.heading: 5. Don't Fear Mistakes
children.content: Natives understand accents Clear vowels matter most Confidence helps communication

sections.heading: Quick Reference Chart
sections.content:
| Vowel | Sound | English Example | | ----- | ----- | ------------------- | | あ a | "ah" | father | | い i | "ee" | see | | う u | "oo" | boot (relaxed lips) | | え e | "eh" | bed | | お o | "oh" | boat (short) |

| Special | Symbol | Function | | ---------- | ------------ | ---------------------------- | | Long vowel | ー or double | Hold sound longer | | Small っ | っ | Brief pause/double consonant | | ん | n/m/ng | Nasal sound (varies) |

sections.heading: Regional Variations
sections.content:
Standard Japanese (Tokyo dialect) is what we teach here. Kansai dialect (Osaka/Kyoto) has different pitch patterns:

Standard: ありがとう (low-high-high-high-high) Kansai: おおきに (different intonation entirely)

Don't worry about dialects initially - standard Japanese is understood nationwide.

sections.heading: Summary
sections.content:
Japanese pronunciation is phonetic and consistent :

✓ 5 vowels (always pronounced the same) ✓ Each syllable equal length ✓ No random stress accents ✓ Spelled = pronounced ✓ R is a tap, not English r/l ✓ Hold long vowels fully ✓ Small っ = pause

Most important: Clear vowels and consistent rhythm. Native speakers are very forgiving of accent - clarity matters more than perfection.

Ready to practice? Use our interactive tools:

Learn Hiragana - Audio for each character Hiragana Reading Practice - Real sentences Katakana Table - Foreign word practice
